Under whatever aspect we regard them it is difficult
to draw any clear line of
distinction between Gneiss
and Mica Schist: considered mineralogicallythey are
the two extremes of a series of foliated crystalline
rocks, between which every shade of variation may
be found: their geological relations are the same:
& the foliation of the two rocks follows exactly the
same laws. Their geographical separation through
Scotland has been drawn most arbitrarily: the
lines which divide them on Macculloch’s Map <s>of
Scotland<\s> have very little meaning, & there are
many large tracts where the coloring might be
reversed without any impropriety. The same
may be said of the <u>Chlorite Schist<\u> series of
Macculloch<s>,<s\> which, where I have seen it, is a
variety belonging to the same class of rocks, but more nearly related to Gneiss than to Schist, in
which the mineral ingredients are more numerous
& more completely separated from each other in
parallel layers than is usual in Gneiss or Mica
<s>Slate<\s> Schist: yet there are many districts in which the separation
of the ingredients of Gneiss into layers is as complete
as in the Chlorite Schist described by Macculloch*,
& in which the Quartz forms layers between one
& two feet thick, alternating with layers of Micaceous
Schist, or with beds of a crystalline rock without foliation or
cleavage. The other varieties of schist described by 
<s>Maculloch<\s> *Western Isles, vol. 2 p 284.
